key_work.title: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
key_work.brief_description: Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films.

end.title: The Cheaters
end.brief_description: An embezzler, Bill Marsh, swears vengeance on a businessman, John Travers, who has turned him in to the police. Twenty years pass, and Marsh emerges from jail and establishes himself as the head of a powerful crime empire, with his daughter, Paula, serving as bait to attract wealthy victims.

links.description: Paulette McDonagh was a pioneering Australian filmmaker. Her third film The Cheaters was made as a silent film on the cusp of the arrival of sound. Retrofitted scenes with added sound failed to make the film a success.
